name: Production Possibilities Curve
description: The PPC simulator introduces the production possibilities curve and how it represents the production between to goods and with the available resources.

leaves.text: shows us the combinations of goods that can be produced.
It is used to model a situation or hypothetical world where only two goods exist.
One good is shown on each axis.
The PPC helps us make choices and illustrate important concepts such as scarcity, resource allocation and opportunity cost.
The PPC is a graphical model to visualise choices given the resources available and the trade-offs between them.
We have limited resources (employees, ingredients, hours in a day) and need to make the best choices.
and could clean the house or watch Netflix.
You have 5 hours available. The x-axis shows the hours you could spend on cleaning and the y-axis shows the hours you could spend on Netflix.
The graph represents the mix (combinations) of hours you could spend on both.

content.data: To clean or not to clean

leaves.text: You could spend 5 hours watching Netflix, but you might regret it later, or you could spend 5 hour cleaning the house, but you probably don't want to.
But you can't use more hours, you only have 5.
For every hour of one activity, the trade-off is one hour of the other activity.
You probably will choose to allocate your
For every good we need an axis to visualise it.
might not be able to visualise it
To visualise two goods you require 2 dimensions (x, y).
For three goods you would require 3 dimensions (x, y and z).
For any amount higher of goods it becomes practically impossible to graph.
pens. It can make 10 units an hour and works 10 hours a day.
Per day it can choose how to spend its hours:
A mix of hours to each ⇒
If you were tasked with making desserts for a bake sale you will need to choose what to make.
This example shows the choice between baking
The PPC is important because it shows all the possible options and what you can bake with the resources (time) you have available.
It also may influence how much money you make from the bake sale.
The PPC represents all possible combinations that can be produced using the available
technology and all factors of production (capital, land, labor, and entrepreneurship).
In this case, it will show you how many batches of  brownies or cookies can be baked given certain factors like your time (labor) and your cooking ingredients (capital).
available to bake the day before the bake sale.
The pre-mixed supermarket box tells you that:
You will need to decide what and how much to bake.
If you spend all the 5 hours
But probably not everyone likes cookies.
If you spend all the 5 hours (300 minutes) baking
But probably not everyone likes brownies.
we can also understand more about the combinations or points.
are a point in the graph. Each point contains an amount of good 1 and good 2 (even if the amount is 0).
Some combinations or points include all the points in purple.
allows us to see what are the different types of combinations.
A point can be attainable or unattainable
then it can be efficient or inefficient
All the possible combinations below and along the line (marked in green) are attainable.
They are attainable since you can produce these points with the resources you have available.
(not including the line) represent combinations that are unattainable or not possible.
They can't be produced since they require resources you don't have.
If you only have 5 hours to bake, you can't bake for 6 hours. Therefore, there is a limit (constraint) to what can be produced. This limit is defined by the
Economics is often concerned with producing the most goods and services for people to enjoy, therefore they care about efficiency.
means that all the resources are optimally  allocated (allocated in the best way).
If you have 5 hours it is only efficient if you use this 5 hours to produce something. For the
, it is not important on which good the resources are spent, as long as all are spent.
If you don't use all the resources then it is inefficient since you could be produce more (and make more people "happy").
All the points below the line are inefficient (not optimal).
This is because you still have either extra cooking ingredients or time to bake. If you allocated (used) these resources better, you could produce a higher amount of brownies and cookies.
These points are efficient since you use all the resources available (time and ingredients) and there is no way you could produce more (unless your resources or technology change).
also reveals a critical factor about the relationship of the goods, the
is what you "sacrifice" to make 1 more unit of a good.
For straight lines, the opportunity cost is always the same (constant).
We will look more at opportunity cost in the next chapter.

The PPC can have different slopes. This will depend on the resources available and the resources necessary to produce a good. The resources that will be necessary in turn can be affected by technology.
Can produce good 1 as well as good 2
Can produce good 2 better than good 1
Can produce good 1 better than good 2
A shift of the curve may happen when the factors of production change.
If a firm increases its productivity (technology) or the amount of work hours, the
would shift right, which means that with the same amount of resources the firm can now produce more of each item.
The shift could benefit the production of

content.data: Will the PPC be always a line?

leaves.text: The PPC will not always be a straight line.
In the real world, the PPC is more likely to be bowed outwards / bend to the right.

This happens specially when more people are included in the PPC. Each person / firm has different abilities and technology available and can produce at different speeds. This allows for more options and bends the curve outwards.
The bent outward shape occurs also due to
This means some people are best at producing
and some others are best at producing
The first people assigned to producing
will produce high amounts of it (since the best are assigned first), but as you assign more people to produce
, the output decreases (as people bad at producing good 1 are forced to produce it instead of good 2).
Assigning people to produce more of a good doesn't assure the same output per person but will actually start decreasing.
Consider a new example of an economy which produces only

Some workers are skilled at making cheese whilst other are better at growing apples. As an economy produces more and more of a good, it is forced to employ less productive resources, causing diminishing marginal returns.
When the PPC is bent outwards, the slope and opportunity cost changes at every
This is due to diminishing marginal returns. At point 1, 90 units of good 1 are already produced, good 1 can't be made productively relative to good 2.
At point 3, 10 units of good 1 are produced, good 1 can be made productively.
The quiz section will start now.
You will get instant feedback after submitting an answer.
In the end, you will receive a grade.
You may redo the quiz, but once started it must be finished.

answers.feedback: The PPC shows us a number of possibilities available.
The PPC is not a channel, it is a curve that is modelled to show us combinations of goods that can be produced.
Correct! It is called the production possibilities curve because it shows us the combinations of goods that can be produced.

content.data: What is the maximum units of Good 1 that can be produced in this scenario?

answers.feedback: Unattainable. The PPc does not go above 60 units.
Unattainable. The PPC does not go above 60 units
Correct! For good 1, the PPC goes to a maximum of 60 units.

content.data: Which of the following PPC depicts the law of the diminishing marginal returns?

answers.feedback: This PPC has constant returns. For straight lines, the opportunity cost is always the same (constant).
This PPC has constant returns. For straight lines, the opportunity cost is always the same (constant).

Correct! This happens specially when more people are included in the PPC. Each person / firm has different abilities and technology available and can produce at different speeds. This allows for more options and bends the curve outwards.

content.data: At which point is the opportunity cost of gaining more economics knowledge/ability highest?

answers.feedback: This is the maximum of history knowledge not economics.
Incorrect. This combination is outside of the PPC.
Incorrect. This combination is not along the PPC
Incorrect. This combination is not along the PPC.
Correct! This combination is not along the PPC

content.data: A restaurant sells all the food it produces. It sells each pizza for $15 and pasta for $10. What combination achieves the greater revenue?

answers.feedback: Revenue would be $100, other combination can yield a higher revenue
Inefficient combination. Revenue can be higher by producing more of ANY good.
